metadata.subject: Indicting a President Is Not Foreclosed: The Complex History - Lawfare

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia

relationships.description: Sender forwarding legal analysis article to recipient
OLC is part of the Department of Justice

analysis.purpose: To share legal analysis about whether a sitting president can be indicted, discussing historical precedents and constitutional questions
analysis.significance: Provides detailed legal analysis of presidential indictment questions with historical context from Watergate and Clinton investigations

notable_quotes: The reality is more complicated. The United States has addressed this question six times in both internal memos and briefs filed in litigation.
The fact that it is permissible to name a sitting president as unindicted co-conspirator, moreover, tends significantly to undermine the only argument against indicting a sitting president.
The history of positions taken by the executive branch of the United States on the indictment of a sitting president is more varied and complex than is generally assumed.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion present - this is a scholarly legal analysis email

illegal_activity.description: This email shares a Lawfare blog article analyzing legal precedents regarding presidential indictment - no first-hand illegal activity discussed

details: References to Lawfare blog article and legal analysis publications

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be sharing publicly available legal analysis from Lawfare blog about presidential indictment questions, relevant to ongoing political discussions in 2018

analysis.summary: Kathy Ruemmler forwards a Lawfare blog article that analyzes the complex legal history of whether a sitting president can be indicted, examining six key historical instances including Watergate and Clinton investigations, and concluding that indictment is not categorically foreclosed despite Office of Legal Counsel opinions to the contrary.
